metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of automatic meteorological observations at the Linze grassland station
metadata.description:
The dataset of automatic meteorological observations was obtained at the Linze grassland station (E100 °04'/N39°15', 1394m) from Oct. 1, 2007 to Oct. 27, 2008. The landscape is dominated by wetland and saline land. 
     Observation items were multilayer (2m, 4m and 10m) of the wind speed and direction, air temperature and humidity, air pressure, precipitation, four components of radiation, the surface temperature, the soil temperature (5cm, 10cm, 20cm and 40cm), and the multilayer soil temperature (2cm, 5cm and 10cm). 
     The dataset was released at different levels: Level1 were transformed raw data and stored in .csv month by month; Level2 were processed data after correction and quality control. As for detailed information, please refer to Meteorological and Hydrological Flux Data Guide.

background: The near-surface atmospheric elements including air temperature, pressure, relative humility, wind, precipitation and radiation are called forcing data to drive hydrological, land surface, and ecological models. Coupling or use of the General Circulation Model (GCM) output to drive the land surface model is an important source of forcing data for large-scale land surface models, however the spatial and temporal resolution can not meet the requirements of a regional scale land surface model and its coarse resolution ignored regional environmental impact assessment. Thus, a regional scale land surface model or land surface data assimilation system needs forcing data with a higher temporal-spatial resolution. Therefore, downscaling GCM output is necessary in order to prepare for a long series of high spatial and temporal resolution forcing data for regional scale or basin-scale land surface, hydrological and ecological simulation and assimilation. Downscaling is a method of obtaining high-resolution climate or climate change information from relatively coarse-resolution GCMs. Dynamic downscaling uses large scale climatic background information to establish higher resolution meteorological distribution fields by GCMs. Regional climate model is considered to be an effective dynamic downscaling method to derive high-resolution local climate information. The model’s physical meaning is clear, it is built on the nonlinear interaction between large scale and regional scale, and can distinguish local features characterized by local topography, vegetation cover and soil hydrological processes, and can be used anywhere independent of observation data with an improved description of local features.
research objective: In order to do the validation of WRF model on simulating forcing data for the Heihe River Basin, daily meteorological observation data from 15 stations of CMA (China Meteorological Administration) and hourly meteorological observation data from seven sites of WATER (Watershed Airborne Telemetry Experimental Research) are used to compare with WRF simulations, with a time range of a whole year for 2008. Thus, the validation accuracy of forcing data from RCM is important before input to drive the land surface model.
methods: The model was validated at 15 surface meteorological stations maintained by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and seven observation-strengthened stations setup by WATER project. In this study, WRF is used for downscaling of weather and climate ranging from one kilometer to thousands of kilometers and used for deriving meteorological parameters required for hydrological models. For this study, two way nested computational domains of 41×55×28 and 101×121×28 grid points and horizontal resolutions of 25 km and 5 km, respectively, have been set. The model is initialized by real boundary conditions using NCAR-NCEP’s Final Analysis (FNL) data (NCEP-DSS083.2, 2009) having a resolution of 1°×1° (111 km×111 km).
dataset: Daily meteorological observation data from 15 stations of CMA (China Meteorological Administration) and hourly meteorological observation data from seven sites of WATER (Watershed Airborne Telemetry Experimental Research) are used to compare with WRF simulations, with a time range of a whole year for 2008. The model was validated at 15 surface meteorological stations maintained by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and seven observation-strengthened stations setup by WATER project. Data from CMA stations are used for daily validation; the WATER’s are for hourly validation. All CMA data in 2008 are used for comparison, the time span of WATER’s are listed in Table 2.
findings: Results show that the average MBE (Mean Bias Error) of daily 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure, 2-m relative humidity and 10-m wind speed were −0.19 °C, −4.49 hPa, 4.08% and 0.92 m/s, the average RMSE (Root Mean Square Error) of them were 2.11 °C, 5.37 hPa, 9.55% and 1.73 m/s, and the average R (correlation coefficient) of them were 0.99, 0.98, 0.80 and 0.55, respectively. The average MBE of hourly 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure, 2-m relative humidity, 10-m wind speed, downward shortwave radiation and downward longwave were −0.16 °C, −6.62 hPa, −5.14%, 0.26 m/s, 33.0 W/m2 and −6.44 W/m2, the average RMSE of them were 2.62 °C, 17.10 hPa, 20.71%, 2.46 m/s, 152.9 W/m2 and 53.5 W/m2, and the average R of them were 0.96, 0.97, 0.70, 0.26, 0.91 and 0.60, respectively. Thus, the following conclusions were obtained: (1) regardless of daily or hourly validation, WRF model simulations of 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure and relative humidity are more reliable, especially for 2-m surface air temperature and surface pressure, the values of MBE were small and R were more than 0.96; (2) the WRF simulating downward shortwave radiation was relatively good, the average R between WRF simulation and hourly observation data was above 0.9, and the average R of downward longwave radiation was 0.6; (3) both wind speed and rainfall simulated from WRF model did not agree well with observation data.

background: Soil moisture is a variable that plays a leading role in surface water and energy balance. The traditional point measurements can just provide a soil moisture distribution in a limited area. The hydrologic models can simulate the soil moisture variation in large spatial and temporal scales. However, the uncertainty in initial model state, model physical parameters, meteorological forcing variables and model equations brings much error in the soil moisture estimation. Many researchers suggested that the most promising approach for estimating soil moisture is the integration of remote sensing surface soil moisture data and a hydrologic model (Kostove and Jackson, 1993). Many researches have been carried out on optimizing a computational model through minimizing the difference between the observation and model simulation results by the re-parameterization (Jarlan et al., 2005; Yang et al., 2009) or re-initialization (Heathman et al., 2003; Huang et al., 2008) of the computational model separately. The re-parameterization approach can improve the model state variables by adjusting uncertain parameters. Since some parameters can hardly be obtained by field measurements, they are often estimated from the experiences or references, which brings much uncertainty to the model parameters. The re-initialization approach does not attribute the simulation errors to the uncertainties of the initial conditions, model parameters or model physical equations. It can adjust the state variables directly and it adopts the updated state variables as the initial field to re-initialize the model. The most effective and popular re-initialization approach is Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF).
research objective: This research developed a one-dimensional soil moisture assimilation scheme based on the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA). In this research, the assimilation scheme combined the EnKF and GA as the assimilation algorithm and it could calibrate the model parameters and model initial state synthetically. This paper proposes a one-dimensional soil moisture assimilation scheme combining the EnKF and GA, which has been illuminated by the assimilation experiment carried out in the Heihe River Basin in Northwest China in 2008.
challenges: There is much uncertainty in the assimilation process, which affects the assimilation results. There is much uncertainty in the model initial state and model parameters in the hydrologic modeling, which brings much error to the soil moisture simulation. It is difficult to develop the adjoint model for the original one to evaluate the derivatives of the cost function with respect to control variables, which are composed of state variables and model parameters to be estimated. It is complicated to develop the adjoint model in practice, which posed many limitations to its application (Qin et al., 2007).
methods: In this assimilation scheme, the soil moisture was taken as the combination point of the hydrologic model and the backscattering model. The DHSVM was coupled with a semi-empirical backscattering model (Oh) to simulate backscattering coefficients. When the ASAR data were available, a cost function was set up based on the gap between the backscattering coefficients from ASAR observation and the backscattering coefficients from the simulations. Then the EnKF was used to optimize the state variables. If the cost function was higher than twice the ASAR observation noises, the simulation was treated as unacceptable. Then the cost function was minimized by the GA approach. The sensitive parameters of the DHSVM were re-parameterized. The simulations were divided into acceptable and unacceptable cases. The EnKF and GA were used to re-initialize and re-parameterize the simulation process. The assimilation experiment was carried out in the Heihe River Basin, Northwest China.
dataset: The Heihe River Basin, located in the arid area of Northwest China, is the second largest inland river basin, with an area of 116 000 km2 and an average annual precipitation of 108 mm. The ASAR images were used as observation data. ASAR images were acquired for several dates and different polarizations with incidence angles between 10º and 60º, operating in C band. The spatial resolution of ASAR is about 12.5 m × 12.5 m. The spatial resolution of the DHSVM simulation was 30 m, so the spatial resolution of ASAR was resampled into 30 m by the bilinear interpolation method.
findings: The results obtained indicate that this assimilation scheme is practical and it can improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimation significantly. The result shows that the model estimate of surface soil moisture was improved by being assimilated with the ASAR data. Additionally, the data assimilation improves the DHSVM model outputs which are more close to the actual values.

background: The commonly applied surface temperature–vegetation index (Ts–VI) triangle method is used to estimate regional evapotranspiration (ET) in arid and semi-arid regions. A practical algorithm based on the Ts–VI triangle method is developed to determine quantitatively the dry and wet edges of this triangle space.
research objective: The objectives of this paper are twofold: (1) to develop an algorithm to determine quantitatively the dry and wet edges for the Ts–VI triangular space in arid and semi-arid areas where wet pixels are not generally easily identified, and (2) to validate with the in-situ ET measurements made by the Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) the ET derived from MODIS/TERRA products using the developed algorithm.
challenges: Problems encountered in the determination of dry and wet edges during the period of our experiment mainly include: (1) only few points that were not contaminated by cloud in the Ts–VI space can be obtained on partly cloudy days in the study area, which will make the Ts–VI triangle method for ET estimates unreliable; and (2) in a short period after a rainfall event, the observed dry edge in the Ts–VI triangle may not indicate pixels with minimum ET for the given Fr due to the non-zero surface soil water content.
methods: In this paper, an iterative process is proposed to determine automatically the two edges in the Ts–Fr triangle space. To apply the above Ts–Fr triangle method to MODIS data, several steps are needed to be performed. Downloading MODIS land surface temperature/emissivity and NDVI products, MODIS Calibrated Radiances and Geolocation products, as well as MODIS Atmospheric Precipitable Water product from the MODIS data and products centers. Screening out the pixels contaminated by cloud and also the pixels with surface elevation far apart from the average of surface elevation in the study area. Estimating the fraction of vegetation (Fr) for each pixel in the study area. Constructing the Ts–Fr triangle space. Determining automatically the dry and wet edges in the Ts–Fr triangle space. Calculating pixel by pixel the combined-effect parameter ϕ. Retrieving evaporative fraction (EF) from the combined-effect parameter ϕ.
dataset: MODIS data products used in this work are land surface temperature/emissivity (MOD11A1 and MOD11_L2), NDVI (MOD13A2), Calibrated Radiances (MOD021KM), Geolocation (MOD03), Precipitable Water (MOD05_L2) products. All 24 clear-sky MODIS data from May 23rd to August 21st over our study area are used to estimate the EF, ET and H using the Ts–Fr triangle method/algorithm.
findings: A practical algorithm was developed for quantitative determination of dry and wet edges for the Ts–VI triangle method from MODIS data and products. This algorithm can provide an estimation of surface net radiation, soil heat flux, evaporative fraction and evapotranspiration at regional scale from MODIS data and products alone. Although assumption of two-step linear interpolation scheme involved in the estimation of the combined-effect parameter ϕ and EF is still questionable and not yet verified directly, a very good agreement is found with the RMSE=25.07 W/m2 when sensible heat flux estimated from MODIS data is compared with that measured by LAS instrument.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how meteorological data is validated against simulation models to ensure accuracy in regional climate studies?
Example.Answer: Meteorological data from 15 stations of the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and hourly data from seven sites of the WATER project are used to validate WRF simulations over the Heihe River Basin for 2008. This involves comparing daily and hourly observed data against the simulated outputs to assess the accuracy of forcing data before driving land surface models.

Example.Question: What is an example of integrating remote sensing data with hydrologic models to improve soil moisture estimation?
Example.Answer: A one-dimensional soil moisture assimilation scheme was developed using the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) to integrate ASAR remote sensing data with the DHSVM hydrologic model. This method was tested in the Heihe River Basin, improving the accuracy of surface soil moisture estimation.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a method used to estimate regional evapotranspiration in arid areas using satellite data?
Example.Answer: The Ts–VI triangle method is applied using MODIS data to estimate regional evapotranspiration in arid regions. This involves determining the dry and wet edges in the Ts–Fr triangle space and using these to calculate evaporative fraction and evapotranspiration. The method is validated with in-situ measurements like those from the Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS).

Definition.Question: What is dynamic downscaling in the context of generating high-resolution climate data?
Definition.Answer: Dynamic downscaling is a method of obtaining high-resolution climate or climate change information from relatively coarse-resolution General Circulation Models (GCMs). It uses large scale climatic background information to establish higher resolution meteorological distribution fields. Regional climate models are considered effective dynamic downscaling methods to derive high-resolution local climate information, as they incorporate the nonlinear interaction between large scale and regional scale, and can distinguish local features like topography, vegetation cover, and soil hydrological processes.

Definition.Question: What role does the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) play in soil moisture estimation?
Definition.Answer: The Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) is used in soil moisture estimation as a re-initialization approach to adjust state variables directly in a hydrologic model. It adopts updated state variables as the initial field to re-initialize the model. This approach is effective in improving model state variables by minimizing the difference between observation and model simulation results, particularly in the context of integrating remote sensing surface soil moisture data with hydrologic models.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for meteorological observations in the 黑河综合遥感联合试验 compare to those used in the WRF model validation study?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods at the 黑河综合遥感联合试验 involve continuous automatic measurements using an automatic weather station, capturing variables like wind speed, temperature, and soil moisture at various heights and depths. In contrast, the WRF model validation study utilizes data from 15 CMA stations and 7 WATER project sites, focusing on daily and hourly meteorological observations to compare with model simulations. The former emphasizes localized, high-resolution data, while the latter integrates broader regional datasets for model validation.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the use of remote sensing data for soil moisture estimation and evapotranspiration assessment within this field?
Comparison.Answer: Both methods utilize remote sensing data to enhance model simulations. The soil moisture estimation combines ASAR imagery with a hydrological model to improve accuracy through data assimilation techniques like the Ensemble Kalman Filter. For evapotranspiration assessment, MODIS data is used to apply the Ts–VI triangle method, estimating ET by identifying dry and wet edges in the data. The similarity lies in the integration of remote sensing data to refine model outputs, while the difference is in the type of remote sensing data and the specific algorithms or methods employed.

Interpretation.Question: What can the observed patterns in soil moisture variations tell us about the effectiveness of combining remote sensing data with hydrologic models for improving model accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of remote sensing surface soil moisture data with a hydrologic model, as seen in the Heihe River Basin experiment, significantly improves the accuracy of soil moisture estimation. This suggests that the approach effectively addresses uncertainty in model parameters and initial conditions, enhancing simulation outputs.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for higher temporal-spatial resolution in forcing data for regional scale land surface models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The spatial and temporal resolution of General Circulation Model (GCM) outputs often cannot meet the requirements of regional scale land surface models, as they ignore regional environmental impact assessments and require downscaling to obtain high-resolution data for hydrological, land surface, and ecological simulations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there uncertainty in the estimation of soil moisture using traditional hydrologic models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainty in soil moisture estimation arises from factors such as initial model state, model physical parameters, meteorological forcing variables, and the model equations themselves. These uncertainties can introduce significant errors in soil moisture simulation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in determining dry and wet edges in the Ts–VI triangle method for ET estimation?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in determining dry and wet edges are primarily due to limited data points not contaminated by clouds on partly cloudy days and the non-zero surface soil water content shortly after rainfall events, which can affect the reliability of the Ts–VI triangle method for evapotranspiration estimates.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating regional scale land surface model data with downscaled GCM outputs on the accuracy of hydrological and ecological simulations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating regional scale land surface model data with downscaled GCM outputs potentially improves the spatial and temporal resolution, which can lead to more accurate hydrological and ecological simulations. This integration can capture local features like topography, vegetation, and soil hydrological processes more effectively, which are often missed by coarse-resolution GCMs.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the effects of using MODIS data products for determining regional evapotranspiration in arid and semi-arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using MODIS data products for determining regional evapotranspiration can provide accurate estimations of surface net radiation, soil heat flux, evaporative fraction, and evapotranspiration. This approach allows for large-scale assessments from satellite data, which is crucial in regions where in-situ measurements are sparse. Despite some assumptions in the method, a good agreement with ground-based measurements suggests its effectiveness.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives might researchers have when developing datasets that integrate remote sensing data with hydrologic models in arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Researchers aim to improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimation by integrating remote sensing data, such as ASAR images, with hydrologic models. This approach addresses uncertainties in traditional soil moisture measurements and model simulations by optimizing state variables and model parameters through data assimilation techniques like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA).

Goal Orientation.Question: Why would it be essential to validate regional climate models with observational data in the context of hydrological and ecological simulations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Validating regional climate models with observational data is crucial to ensure the accuracy of forcing data that drive land surface models. This validation helps in refining the model outputs to better represent local climatic conditions, which is vital for effective hydrological, land surface, and ecological simulations and assessments. The process involves comparing model simulations with data from meteorological stations to improve model reliability and precision.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to ensure the quality and reliability of meteorological data collected from automatic weather stations in regional land surface modeling?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Meteorological data from automatic weather stations are initially converted to a standardized format and stored monthly as Level1 data. They undergo preliminary data analysis, error correction, and quality control before being archived as Level2 data. This process ensures high data quality for modeling purposes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) utilized in the assimilation of soil moisture data to enhance model accuracy, and what steps are involved in its implementation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The EnKF is used in conjunction with a genetic algorithm to optimize state variables and calibrate model parameters. The process involves setting up a cost function based on the gap between observed and simulated backscattering coefficients. If the cost is too high, the simulation is deemed unacceptable, and parameters are re-parameterized using the genetic algorithm, followed by re-initialization with the EnKF.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the downscaling of General Circulation Model (GCM) output to meet the resolution requirements of regional scale land surface models?
Enablement.Answer: Dynamic downscaling is used to obtain high-resolution climate or climate change information from relatively coarse-resolution GCMs. It uses large-scale climatic background information to establish higher resolution meteorological distribution fields, and the Regional Climate Model is considered an effective method for deriving high-resolution local climate information, distinguishing local features characterized by topography, vegetation cover, and soil hydrological processes.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of remote sensing data and hydrologic models enable improved soil moisture estimation?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of remote sensing surface soil moisture data and a hydrologic model, such as through the use of the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA), helps calibrate the model parameters and initial state. This approach can improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimation by optimizing state variables and minimizing the difference between observation and model simulations, as demonstrated in experiments in Heihe River Basin.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements allow for the estimation of evapotranspiration using the Ts–VI triangle method in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The development of an algorithm to quantitatively determine the dry and wet edges for the Ts–VI triangular space, using MODIS data products, enables the estimation of surface net radiation, soil heat flux, evaporative fraction, and evapotranspiration at a regional scale. This involves processing MODIS land surface temperature/emissivity, NDVI, Calibrated Radiances, Geolocation, and Precipitable Water products to construct the Ts–Fr triangle space and retrieve evaporative fraction.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in obtaining high-resolution forcing data for regional scale land surface models?
Expectation.Answer: Forcing data for regional scale land surface models require high temporal-spatial resolution, which is not typically met by the coarse resolution of General Circulation Models (GCMs). Dynamic downscaling using regional climate models can improve resolution, but the process involves complexities such as accurately capturing local features influenced by topography, vegetation, and soil hydrological processes.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise in the assimilation of soil moisture data with hydrologic models, and how might these affect expected outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: The assimilation process is fraught with uncertainties in model initial states, parameters, and equations, which lead to errors in soil moisture estimation. Developing an adjoint model for evaluating derivatives of the cost function is complex, posing limitations to practical application and affecting the accuracy of the integration of remote sensing data with hydrologic models.

Expectation.Question: Why might the estimation of evapotranspiration in arid regions be problematic using the Ts–VI triangle method?
Expectation.Answer: In arid regions, determining dry and wet edges for the Ts–VI triangle is challenging, particularly on partly cloudy days or shortly after rainfall events, where few uncontaminated data points are available. This limits the reliability of the method, as the observed dry edge may not accurately reflect minimum evapotranspiration rates due to residual soil moisture.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset could be effectively utilized for driving hydrological, land surface, and ecological models, especially considering the need for high temporal-spatial resolution.
Assertion.Answer: Forcing data for hydrological, land surface, and ecological models require high temporal-spatial resolution. This can be achieved through downscaling methods that derive high-resolution local climate information from coarse-resolution General Circulation Models (GCMs). Dynamic downscaling using regional climate models can provide the necessary resolution by establishing higher resolution meteorological distribution fields.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how MODIS data alone can be used to estimate evapotranspiration and other surface energy parameters at a regional scale.
Assertion.Answer: MODIS data products, such as land surface temperature/emissivity and NDVI, are used to construct a Ts–Fr triangle space, which helps estimate surface energy parameters like evapotranspiration. An algorithm determines the dry and wet edges, enabling the calculation of the evaporative fraction and other related parameters across the region by processing clear-sky data from MODIS.
